text: [Music]
well the first thing I would say is that
I guess we've come to think that you
know the reason we have educational
inequity is is it's a function of many
things working together you know it's a
function of the fact that the kids in
low-income communities are facing huge
extra challenges that kids in other
communities simply aren't facing just as
a function of growing up in poverty um
uh largely you know the kids we serving
are kids of color who face all sorts of
other challenges as a function of
societal discrimination Etc and and then
they're showing up at schools and school
systems that arguably have not
historically had the mission and and
certainly don't have the resources and
the capacity to take kids who face extra
challenges and actually put them on a
Level Playing Field
um so and and why do we have all of that
because of you know our policies and
practices and really the prevailing
ideology of our country so as we step
back and think about okay so how do we
solve the problem we think well you know
on the one hand we need to do a lot to
take some of the pressure off of schools
you know if we can improve the quality
of you know economies in urban and rural
areas and the quality of Social Services
and Health Services and um and such you
know we can do a l lot to make our work
easier at the same time what what the
teachers have been talking about and the
school leaders are showing us is that
even as our socioeconomic disparities
persist it's within our power as a
society to build the capacity within our
schools and school systems to actually
take kids who face extra challenges and
truly put them on a Level Playing Field
and I guess what we've come to see over
time is that you know as I said before
there's nothing magical or elusive about
it right like if you go into one of
these very high performing schools and
ask um the person running the school
what what's going on here H how are you
all I mean you know I think about a guy
named Chris barbick who um has started a
now collection of schools in Houston
Texas um you know 7% of the kids in this
low-income community in Houston actually
graduate from college and the kids who
go to Chris's Middle School which turns
into a high school 90% of them graduate
from college so you just think okay
there's something different going on in
this school what is it and if you asked
Chris he would say nothing magical you
know and and and you think what but no
it's true there is a school leader who
deeply knows that the kids he's working
with have every bit as much potential as
the kids in you know River Oaks which is
the kind of wealthier community in
Houston um and absolutely could graduate
from college and and have the world of
opportunities open to them he has
attracted teachers at every level of his
school who deeply believe the same thing
and are willing to do whatever it takes
to ensure that their kids fulfill that
potential he's built an incredibly
powerful culture in his school a culture
of achievement uh which aligns the kids
and their families and and the teachers
as well around this goal that we're
going to do whatever it takes to
graduate from college and have real
choices in life um and and the school
itself is just committed to achieving
that end and to the continuous
Improvement it would take to get there I
mean it's it's like all all the basics
you know um and I guess I I think that's
an important recognition that that the
same thing that accounts for Success
really in any sector is what accounts
for success in education and so what we
need is you know the same kind of
investment in in talent development at
every level of the system um in
technology systems in in all the things
that that our highest performing
corporations are are investing in um so
I guess those are the things that that
would shape my policy
recommendations I think I guess I think
it's important that as a nation
we continue to commit ourselves to
attaining measurable progress in closing
achievement gaps so you know this kind
of accountability framework that was
initially implemented Within No Child
Left Behind this federal law we would
say is is critical you know we would we
would say in fact you know we need to
make greater investments in ensuring
that we have very rigorous standards and
very helpful useful meaningful
assessments so that we can put you know
in the hands of our teachers and our
kids actually as well and and the kids'
parents um a a real understanding of
where they are against the standards
that all kids should should meet and
should have the opportunity to meet so
we would say that that providing that
framework is is really important and
then I think the question is you know
what can we do at the federal level to
inspire the level of local leadership
and local initiative and local capacity
necessary to really meet rigorous
standards I I personally think there's
only so much we can do from the federal
level um but I do think we can you know
set up a set of uh uh sort of policy
that lead Folks at the local level um
who who who are aspiring to this to have

don't know if that makes sense but I
think I think there's a tendency to
think that we can almost micromanage

as much as we would all like to be able
to do that I think if anything we've
seen real evidence in the last uh eight
years since since No Child Left Behind
uh was was implemented that you know
what the a federal mandate can only
accomplish so much ultimately this is
about local leadership and an
initiative we're excited to have I mean
first of all I would say we'd be excited

Pursuit
all of these uh proposals around teacher

a talent mindset meaning we should be

with how do we attract extremely
